metadata.title: Indonesia Carbon Tax & Environmental Regulations 2025
metadata.legalFramework: Law No. 7/2021 on Tax Harmonization, Presidential Regulation No. 98/2021
metadata.source: DJP, OECD, ICAP, Ministry of Finance

legalBasis.law: Law No. 7 of 2021 on Harmonization of Tax Regulations
legalBasis.presidentialRegulation: Presidential Regulation No. 98 of 2021 on Implementation of Carbon Economic Value

taxRate.classification: Low bracket compared to other countries (OECD 2018)

implementationStatus.actualStatus: DELAYED - Not implemented until 2025 in most sectors
implementationStatus.reason: Economic considerations, industry pushback, phased approach

emissionsTradingSystem.name: Indonesia ETS (Emissions Trading System)
emissionsTradingSystem.regulation: OJK Regulation (POJK) Number 14 of 2023 on Carbon Trading

capAndTrade.mechanism: Companies receive emission allowances (cap), trade excess, pay carbon tax if exceed

phase1.covered: Coal-fired power plants (CFPPs) connected to grid

covered: Captive coal-fired power plants (not connected to grid)

allowanceAllocation.benchmark: Emission intensity per unit of output

carbonTaxApplication.description: Facilities failing ETS obligations subject to carbon tax

calculation.formula: Carbon Tax = (Actual Emissions - Allowance) × IDR 30/kg CO2e

carbonTaxApplication.reporting: Annual emissions report to Ministry of Environment

2025.source: Carbon tax study (Indonesia Ministry of Finance)

revenueUtilization: Just transition support (coal industry workers retraining)

incentives.appliesTo: Clean technology equipment (solar panels, wind turbines)

forCoveredFacilities: Install emissions monitoring equipment (CEMS - Continuous Emissions Monitoring System)
Submit annual emissions report (verified by third-party auditor)
Pay carbon tax if exceed allowance

reporting.penalty: IDR 5M - 50M for non-reporting or false reporting

carbonBorderAdjustment.description: EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) - affecting Indonesian exports
impact: Indonesian exports to EU subject to carbon price
Industries: Steel, cement, aluminum, fertilizers, electricity
Incentive: Implement domestic carbon pricing to avoid double taxation
carbonBorderAdjustment.mitigation: Indonesia ETS + carbon tax may offset CBAM charges (with equivalence recognition)

climatFinance.description: Indonesia to receive USD 20B climate finance (G20 JETP - Just Energy Transition Partnership)

highEmitters.impact: High carbon tax liability (if exceed allowance)
highEmitters.strategy: Invest in emission reduction (efficiency improvements, CCS), purchase carbon credits
Switch to alternative fuels (biomass, waste-derived), improve kiln efficiency
Electric arc furnaces (vs blast furnaces), scrap recycling

lowEmitters.opportunity: Generate carbon credits, sell to high emitters

lowEmitters.indirect: Higher electricity costs (if power plants pass carbon cost to consumers)

forCoveredFacilities: Phase 2 (2025): Captive CFPPs, gas plants, cement, steel, petrochemical → Register with IDXCarbon
Install CEMS (Continuous Emissions Monitoring) - Cost IDR 500M - 2B
Develop emission reduction plan (avoid carbon tax)
Consider carbon credit purchase (if cheaper than emission reduction)
forNonCoveredBusinesses: Monitor carbon tax expansion (may cover more sectors post-2025)
Track electricity costs (power plants may pass carbon cost to consumers)
Invest in energy efficiency (reduce electricity consumption)
taxIncentives: R&D for emission reduction: Super Deduction 200% (IDR 100M R&D → IDR 44M tax savings)
Renewable energy projects: Tax Holiday (100% exemption 5-20 years)
strategicPlanning: Carbon cost: IDR 30/kg CO2e (low now, likely to increase post-2025)
Future-proof: Invest in emission reduction early (avoid future higher carbon price)
Carbon credits: Generate/purchase to offset emissions
Renewable energy: Switch to clean power (avoid carbon cost + cost savings)

quickReference.phase2: 2025 onwards (captive CFPPs, gas, cement, steel, petrochemical)
